tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Who can recount the mighty acts of Yahweh ... deeds?
tn.text: The author asks this question to praise God and does not expect an answer. AT: "No one can recount the mighty acts of Yahweh ... deeds." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"deeds that are worthy of praise"
The phrase "call to mind" means to remember something. AT: "remember me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "chosen" refers to Yahweh's chosen people. AT: "of your chosen people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: rejoice in the gladness ... and glory
tn.text: These are things that David says he will do, along with "seeing the prosperity of your chosen." The missing words may be added. AT: "I will rejoice in the gladness ... and I will glory" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"joy" or "delight"

Here the phrase "your inheritance" refers to the Isrealites, who are Yahweh's chosen people. Here "glory" means "to boast about" something; in this case they are boasting about Yahweh. AT: "boast of your greatness with your people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: did not appreciate your marvelous deeds
tn.text: "were not grateful for the marvelous deed you did"

tn.ref: at the sea ... the Sea of Reeds
tn.text: These two phrases refer to the same sea. The second is the name of the sea.
"Yet" or "Even so"
Here "his name" refers to Yahweh. AT: "for the sake of his own reputation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: through the depths, as through a wilderness
tn.text: Here David compares the way that Yahweh led the Isrealites through the Sea of Reeds to the way people can be led across the dry ground of a wilderness. "The depths" refers the riverbed that appeared after Yahweh parted the waters. AT: "through the Seas of Reeds on dry ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He saved them from the hand ... and he rescued them from the hand
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize that Yahweh saved them from their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: the hand of those who hated them
tn.text: Here "hand" refers to power or control. AT: "the power of those who hated them" or "the control of those who hated them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a polite way to talk about them drowning. AT: "drowned their enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Here the word "they" refers to "their ancestors" and the word "his" refers to "Yahweh".

tn.ref: they did not wait for his instructions
tn.text: It is implied that they did things without waiting to find out what Yahweh wanted them to go. AT: "they did things without first waiting for Yahweh's instructions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"cravings that could not be satisfied"
"They rebelled against God"
"overtook" or "took over"

Here David speaks about Yahweh causing the people to be afflicted by a disease as if Yahweh sent a disease to them in the same way that someone sends a person or a messenger. AT: "but he caused a disease to consume their bodies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the Israelites' camp in the wilderness. AT: "In the camp in the wilderness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The earth opened and swallowed up
tn.text: Here how the ground opens up and buries the people is being compared to how a creature swallows something. AT: "The earth opened and buried" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This was an official who rebelled against Moses. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: and covered the followers of Abiram
tn.text: The followers of Abiram were also buried when the earth opened and buried Dathan. AT: "and it also covered the followers of Abiram" or "and it also buried the followers of Abiram" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This was an official who rebelled against Moses. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Fire broke out among them; the fire consumed the wicked
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same things and are written together to emphasize how the wicked people were killed by the fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: They made a calf at Horeb and worshiped a cast metal figure
tn.text: This information can be reordered so that it is clear that the calf was the cast metal figure. AT: "At Horeb, they made a cast metal figure of a calf and worshiped it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: They traded the glory of God for the image of a bull
tn.text: This means that instead of worshiping God they worshiped the image of the bull. AT: "They traded worshiping the glory of God to worship the image of a bull" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here God is referred to by his glory. AT: "their glorious God" or "God who is glorious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the land where Ham's descendants lived. AT: "the land where Ham's descendant live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_possession]])
"awesome things"

tn.ref: intervened with him in the breach ... from destroying them
tn.text: Here David speaks about Moses persuading Yahweh not to destroy the Israelites as intervening with him in the breach. AT: "stood between Yahweh and the Israelites and begged Yahweh to not destroy them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"complained"
This refers to Yahweh's promise that he would allow them to take the land of Canaan as their possession.
The word "his" refers to Yahweh. Also, it was custom to raise a hand when swearing an oath.

tn.ref: scatter their descendants ... in foreign lands
tn.text: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. AT: "and that he would make their descendants live in foreign lands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This means to disperse or spread out something.

tn.ref: the sacrifices offered to the dead
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the sacrifices that they offered to the dead" See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"The dead" refers to the idols and gods that the Israelites were worshiping. AT: "to gods who are dead" or "to lifeless gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"a plague spread"
"angered him"

Phinehas intervened among the people, punishing them for their sin. This can be made clear. AT: "Then Phinehas rose to intervene among the people because of their sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: It was counted to him as a righteous deed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "People credited it to him as a righteous deed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

Moses suffered because of the peoples' sin. Here the word "them" is a pronoun for the people and a metonym referring to their sin. AT: "suffered because of their actions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: but they mingled with the nations
tn.text: Hey David speaks of the people intermarrying with the women from other nations as "mingling" with them. AT: "but they mixed in marriage with the other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: which became a snare to them
tn.text: The idols became a snare to them.

tn.ref: They shed innocent blood, the blood of their sons and of their daughters
tn.text: The phrase "shedding blood" is a descriptive  euphemism used for "killing." AT: "They shed innocent blood when they killed their sons and daughters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: They were defiled by their deeds
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Their deeds defiled them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: in their actions they were like prostitutes
tn.text: Here David compares their unfaithfulness to Yahweh to the unfaithfulness of a prostitute. AT: "they were as unfaithful to Yahweh as prostitutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: So Yahweh was angry with his people ... he despised his own people
tn.text: "So Yahweh was angry with his people and despised them"

tn.ref: He gave them into the hand of the nations
tn.text: Here "hand" refers to power or control. AT: "God allowed the nations to take control of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"people who hated them"

tn.ref: and they were brought into subjection to their authority
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and their enemies caused them to be subject to their authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: were brought low by their own sin
tn.text: Here the phrase "brought low" means to be destroyed. Also, this can be stated in active form. AT: "their sin ruined them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Yet" or "Even so." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:106:008|106:8]].
"their affliction" or "their suffering"
The phrase "call to mind" means to remember something. AT: "remembered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"and he had compassion towards them"
"their captors." This refers to the Isrealites' enemies who had taken them captive.
"to be compassionate on them"
Here 106:48 is more than the end of this psalm. It is the closing statement for all of Book 4 of the Psalms, which starts at Psalm 90 and ends with Psalm 106.

tn.ref: May Yahweh the God of Israel be praised
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May people praise Yahweh the God of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here Yahweh is referred to by his "holy name." AT: "to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to two extremes and means for all time. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:041:013|41:13]]. AT: "for all eternity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
